typically that means either greenfield projects where you don't have an application now which

an entire existing application and then there are there's other points
on the spectrum you might be replacing a single module which is kind of like replacing an existing app or you might be replacing a

developers simply don't have the luxury of being able to extensively redesign
what they've got in many cases they have an existing application and they're allowed to refine
existing views and replace individual pieces within a view but that's about as much as they're able
to do so that's where we're aimed at today is what are the major opportunities
for you in that situation to get some better ux now what all of these have in common is
that there is an investigation and understanding phase what's in your case when you're trying to
refine an existing view that would mean what are some of the things the users are struggling with
right now what is inadequate about the existing view and then there is an ideation phase
where you go through the process of trying to come up with better ideas for this particular chunk of the screen
so that the users will have a better experience and then when you have several ideas you go through evaluation
now the difference here is that this happens in a very rapid cycle it might be uh half of an afternoon two
or three hours perhaps that you go and observe some users and find out that this particular piece of
the screen isn't as good as it could be you sketch out some ideas you show them around to some people
decide the one you like best and then you're ready to implement whereas in a full ux design
project say for a greenfield project or a replacement we might spend as much as two weeks with several days in user
observation we analyze those observations and we come up with lots of ideas for lots of different views so i'm today
looking at zeroing right in on the things that you can do for in that situation where you're just

do i have an opinion on pagination versus infinite scroll yeah for either dead grids or card use yes i do uh
i find that most users don't like infinite scroll and it also takes away the ability to
put things at the bottom of the screen because you scroll down to see it and you just get more records so
it's um there are places where it works okay but i think it kind of became
a little bit of a fad a little bit of a trend in general i think most users do like pagination but you have to make
it very clean and very visible and really easy to see and in general when you paginate
my preference is that you paginate and scroll with the new pages but that you but that
you don't take away the old data when you paginate to new data now that can get you in trouble if
you've got too much data so you sort of build things on a case-by-case basis there
but the optimal if somebody is is looking at let's say 50 records at a time is that you keep
the previous 50 and stack on another 50 and and so forth in general i don't like returning a lot of
records users don't look at 500 records so there's no point in returning that many
and and that also kind of applies to pagination past a certain point they probably aren't going to be scrolling through
that whole big list so kind of design to their circumstances but present the information in chunks
hold on to the old chunks show the new chunks of information that's my my starting point uh for a design now understand that i
don't like giving absolute recommendations about these things because they think it varies too much with circumstances
there are there are almost always exceptional cases in which very any design that's
commonly used there's probably a case in which it's the best design or close to the best
design so i don't want to be dogmatic about any of any of these recommendations
um careful with with relying on color to convey information is it would break accessibility well it doesn't have to break
accessibility if it's only color that's true but what you want to do in general is to also vary instead
in addition to varying color you want to vary the hue so that when p when you've got red or
green that you that the red and the green still look different even to somebody that's colorblind
and then that's where using shapes comes in as a good way to do it because um uh
people with colorblindness don't have any trouble with shapes either so yeah you have to
